resources.string: LingVels
WELCOME TO
LINGVELS
Start
Ba-room, ba-room, ba-room, baripity, baripity, baripity, baripity — Good.
His dad had the pickup .....
He could get up now. Jess ..... out of bed and into his overalls.
He didn’t worry about a shirt because once he began running he would be hot as popping grease
even if the morning air was chill, or shoes because
the bottoms of his feet were by now as tough as his worn-out sneakers.
“Where you going, Jess?“
May Belle lifted herself up sleepily from the double bed where she and Joyce Ann slept.
“Sh!“
The walls were thin. Momma would be mad as flies in a fruit jar if they woke her up this time of day.
He patted May Belle’s hair and yanked the twisted sheet up to her small chin.
“Just over the cow field.“
“Gonna run?“
“Maybe.“
Of course, he was going to run.
He ..... up early every day all summer to run.
He figured if he worked at it, he could be the fastest runner in the fifth grade when school opened up.
He had to be the fastest—not one of the fastest or next to the fastest, but the fastest. The very best.
He tiptoed out of the house. The place was so ..... that it screeched whenever you put your foot down.
But Jess had found that if you tiptoed, it gave only a low moan,
and he could usually get outdoors without waking Momma or Ellie or Brenda or Joyce Ann.
May Belle was another matter. She was going on seven, and she worshiped him, which was OK sometimes.
He began to trot ..... the yard. His breath was coming out in little puffs — cold for August.
But it was early yet. By noontime when his mom would have him out working, it would be hot enough.
Miss Bessie stared at him sleepily as he climbed across the scrap heap, over the fence, and into the cow field.
“Moo—oo.“
“Hey, Miss Bessie. Just go on back to sleep.“
Miss Bessie strolled over to a greenish patch and yanked up a mouthful.
“That’a girl. Just eat your breakfast. Don’t ..... me no mind.“
He always started at the northwest corner of the field, crouched over like the runners he had seen on Wide World of Sports.
He took off flying around the cow field.
Miss Bessie strolled toward the center, still following him with her droopy eyes, chewing slowly.
His straw-colored hair flapped hard against his forehead, and his arms and legs flew out every which way.
He ..... to run properly, but he was long-legged for a ten-year-old, and no one had more grit than he.
Lark Creek Elementary was short on everything, especially athletic equipment,
so all the balls went to the upper grades at recess time after lunch.
So the lower-grade boys had started this running thing.
They would all line up on the far side of the lower field and race to a line they’d toed across at the other end.
One time last year Jesse had won. Not just the first heat but the whole shebang.
Only once. But it had put into his mouth a taste for winning.
For the rest of that day, and until after lunch on the next,
he had been “the fastest kid in the third, fourth, and fifth grades,” and he only a fourth grader.
On Tuesday, Wayne Pettis had won again as usual.
But this year Wayne Pettis would be in the sixth grade.
Anybody had a chance to be the fastest runner, and by Miss Bessie, this year it ..... be Jesse Oliver Aarons, Jr.
He could hear the third-grade boys screaming him on.
They would follow him around like a country-music star. Even his dad would be proud.
Jess rounded the corner. His body was begging him to quit, but Jess pushed it on.
He had to let that puny chest of his know who was boss.
“Jess!”
She was yelling from the other side of the scrap heap.
“Momma says you gotta come in and eat now. Leave the milking til later.”
Oh, crud. He’d run too long. Now everyone would know he’d been out and start in on him.
“Yeah, OK.”
He turned, still running, and headed for the scrap heap.
Without breaking his rhythm, he climbed over the fence, thumped May Belle on the head, and trotted on to the house.
“We-ell, look at the big Olympic star!”
Ellie banged two cups onto the table, so that the strong, black coffee sloshed out.
“Sweating like a knock-kneed mule.”
Jess pushed his damp hair out of his face and plunked down on the wooden bench.
He dumped two spoonfuls of sugar into his cup and slurped to keep the hot coffee from ..... his mouth.
“Oooo, Momma, he stinks. Make him wash.”
Brenda pinched her nose with her pinky crooked delicately.
“Get over here to the sink and wash yourself.”
“And step on it. These grits are scorching the bottom of the pot already.”
“Momma! Not again!”
Lord, he was tired. There wasn’t a muscle in his body that didn’t ache.
“You heard what Momma said.”
“I can’t stand it, Momma! Make him get his smelly self off this bench.”
Jess put his cheek down on the bare wood of the tabletop.
“Jess-see! And put on a shirt.”
“Yes’m.”
He dragged himself to the sink. The water he flipped on his face and up his arms ..... like ice.
His hot skin crawled under the cold drops.
May Belle was standing in the kitchen door watching him.
“Get me a shirt, May Belle.”
“You shouldn’t ought to beat me in the head.”
And she went off obediently to fetch his T-shirt. Good old May Belle.
Joyce Ann would have been screaming yet from that little tap. Four-year-olds were a pure pain.
His mother announced as they were finishing the grits and red gravy.
“I got plenty of chores needs ..... around here this morning.”
His mother was from Georgia and still cooked like it.
Ellie and Brenda squawked in concert.
“Momma, you promised me and Brenda we could go to Millsburg for school shopping.”
“You ain’t got no money for school shopping!”
“Momma. We’re just going to look around. Christmas! You don’t want us to have no fun at all.”
“Any fun.”
“Oh, shuttup.”
Ellie ignored her.
“Miss Timmons is coming by to pick us up. I told Lollie Sunday you said it was OK.“
“I feel dumb calling her and saying you changed your mind.”
“Oh, all right. But I ain’t got no money to give you.”
“I know, Momma. We’ll just take the five dollars Daddy promised us. No more’n that.”
“What five dollars?”
“Oh, Momma, you remember.”
Ellie’s voice was sweeter than a melted Mars Bar.
“Daddy said last week we girls were going to have something for school.”
“Oh, take it.”
Mother angrily reached for her cracked vinyl purse on the shelf above the stove and counted out five wrinkled bills.
“Momma, can’t we have just one more? So it’ll be three each?”
“No!”
“Momma, you can’t buy nothing for two fifty. Just one little pack of notebook paper’s gone up to…”
“No!”
Ellie got up noisily and began to clear the table.
“Your turn to wash, Brenda.”
“Awww, Ellie.”
Ellie jabbed her with a spoon. Brenda shut up her mouth.
She wasn’t ..... smart as Ellie, but even she knew not to push Momma too far.
Which left Jess to do the work as usual.
“All right, Jesse. Get your lazy self off that bench.”
“Miss Bessie’s bag is probably dragging ground by now. And you still got beans to pick.“
“OK, Momma. I’m going.”
It was May Belle who came to tell him in the bean patch that people were moving into the old Perkins place down on the next farm.
Jess wiped his hair out of his eyes and squinted. Sure enough.
A U-Haul was parked right by the door. One of those big jointed ones.
These people had a lot of junk. But they wouldn’t last.
The Perkins place was one of those ratty old country houses you moved into
because you had no decent place to go and moved out of as quickly as you could.
He thought later how peculiar it was that here was probably the biggest thing in his life, and he had shrugged it off as nothing.
The flies were buzzing ..... his sweating face and shoulders.
He dropped the beans into the bucket and swatted with both hands.
“Get me my shirt, May Belle.”
The flies were more important than any U-Haul.
May Belle jogged to the end of the row and picked up his T-shirt from where it ..... discarded earlier.
She walked back holding it with two fingers way out in front of her.
“Oooo, it stinks!”
“Shuttup!”
He grabbed the shirt away from her.
